div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, December 22, 1900
div1.p:
Still Fumbling with Yellow Fever.
Very naturally we follow with almost
thrilling interest the investigations of our
medical amateurs into the causes, condi-
tions, symptoms, and treatment of yellow
fever. We have had a great deal of talent at
our disposal in Cuba since January 1, 1899
There were all sorts of reports, conjec-
tures, and solemn announcements. We
were told by Gen. Wood that brooms,
shovels, carbolic acid, and sewers would
kill yellow fever absolutely. How many
hundreds of thousands of dollars were ex-
pended in this way we do not quite re-
call. In fact, it does not matter. Theo-
ries were rife, hypotheses could be gath-
ered like blackberries; everybody knew it
all, and had his private prophylactic, so to
speak, on tap.

Since then our old friend, yellow fever,
has been busy with the various compla-
cent declarations of the talent. It has
challenged and disproved and laughed at
every solemn dogma proclaimed by the
anointed. We find, for example, in the
Engineering News the ingenuous admis-
sion by Surgeon Gorgas, who has been
prominent as a discoverer and pioneer:

“One remarkable feature of this year's epidemic
(in Havana) was that yellow fever cases occurred
to an unusual extent in the more modern and better
built portions of the city, considerably removed
from what were formerly considered the centers of
disease.”

There is nothing like really industrious
investigation. Surgeon Gorgas has now
realized what every yellow fever expert in
New Orleans knew twenty-five years ago
--that yellow fever is not a filth disease,
and that its origin cannot be determined
or its spread measured by the so-called
scientific sanitation of the day. His inno-
cent surprise when he learned that yel-
low fever attacked the new, clean, well-
kept suburbs of Havana and treated with
scornful avoidance the alleged “centers
of infection” is very touching, but not at
all unexpected. The same phenomenon--
if we may call it so--has been familiar to
the New Orleans faculty for half a cen-
tury. In the great epidemic of 1878 the
disease made its first appearance in the
Garden District--the most beautiful and
well-kept part of the city, where there
were only four to six residences on every
block, and where premises were kept like
a flower pot. Down town, in the old French
Quarter, crowded, ill-drained, with the
basins--heads of canals leading into Lake
Pontchartrain--and the swarming popula-
tion packed in miserable, unkempt dwell-
ings--down there, the epidemic paid its
latest visit. That district, with its reeking
and malodorous gutters, its foul premises,
and its frightful physical conditions, was
the very last to be attacked. The yel-
low fever exhausted the material in the
Garden District before it invaded the
slums. Surgeon Gorgas has at last real-
ized a fact with which every yellow fever
expert in New Orleans has been familiar
for the past forty years.

We shall waste no time on this new
“mosquito hypothesis,” further than to sug-
gest that it is as ridiculous as the broom,
shovel, carbolic acid, and sewerage hy-
pothesis. It occurs to us to say, only,
that until some gentleman discovers the
cause of yellow fever, other gentlemen
will be wise to cut short their speculations
as to its spread and propagation and de-
vote themselves humbly to its treatment.
The latter is easy. The rest of it is so far
beyond the powers of the select.
